titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Artmakers Records MSS.564
titlestmt.author: Rachel Searcy and Lauren Stark

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-11-03 16:36:06 UTC.

physdesc.extent: in 11 manuscript boxes, 2 half manuscript boxes, 1 half manuscript box, 5 small flat boxes, 9 oversized flat boxes, 17 flat-file folders, 2 rolled storage boxes, 6 folders in 3 shared oversized flat boxes, and 29 computer disks in 8 shared card boxes and 1 shared half manuscript box

did.abstract: Artmakers Inc. is a community mural organization that develops and creates politically-oriented public art relevant to the lives and concerns of the neighborhoods in which the murals are. Artmakers was established in 1983 and has created over 50 murals nationally and internationally, with a strong focus on New York City. The group is artist-run, and works in collaboration with many community organizations. This collection consists of materials in paper and electronic format documenting the activities and creative works of the Artmakers Inc. collective from the 1980s to the 2010s. Materials in this collection include correspondence, project documentation, photographs, books and other publications, flyers and other ephemera, artist portfolios, research files, and process documentation for murals and other works.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
did.langmaterial: Materials are primarily in English, with a few materials in Spanish.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Jane Weissman in November 2018 and February 2019; the accession numbers associated with these gifts are 2018.131 and 2019.032.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection has been arranged into two series, chronologically within each one. The series arrangement is as follows:
Series II. Murals, Exhibitions, and Projects

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Artmakers Inc. is a community mural organization that develops and creates politically-oriented public art relevant to the lives and concerns of the neighborhoods in which the murals are located. Artmakers was established in 1983 and has created over 50 murals nationally and internationally, the majority of which are in New York City. The group is artist-run, and works in collaboration with many community organizations, including block associations, schools, community gardens, homeless shelters, health care facilities, and other artist groups, to develop mural projects. The organization also offers an apprenticeship program for youth to build their artistic abilities and professional skills.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact Fales Library with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Born-Digital Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. An access terminal for born-digital materials in the collection is available by appointment for reading room viewing and listening only. Researchers may view an item's original container and/or carrier, but the physical carriers themselves are not available for use because of preservation concerns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Artmakers Records; MSS 564; box number; folder number or item identifier; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning, materials were rehoused in archival boxes and described on the collection-level with a box-level inventory. Born-digital items were identified, physically separated, and inventoried.

At the time of processing, materials were rehoused in archival folders and legal manuscript boxes. Materials were arranged into two series and inventoried at the file level. Many items were removed from non-archival sleeves and photographs were removed from photo albums. Financial materials (bank statements, receipts, and invoices), duplicate publications and documents, publications available online, and documents with sensitive personal information were removed. Born-digital materials have been forensically imaged, analyzed, and described. New York University Libraries follow professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity and authenticity of the content.
In June 2025, additional materials were found in the vault; they were rehoused in flat file folders and incorporated intellectually into the finding aid.

In October 2025, oversized materials and rolled items were returned from Preservation, after being rehoused in appropriate sized containers, and intellectually integrated into the inventory. Two posters were cleaned for inactive mold.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of materials in paper and electronic format documenting the activities and creative works of the Artmakers Inc. collective from the 1980s to the late 2010s. Also included are materials from Cityarts Workshop (later, Cityarts, Inc.), an organization that existed prior to, and concurrently with, the founding of Artmakers and shared many of its artists. Materials in this collection include correspondence; project documentation such as preparatory drawings and paintings; books and other publications; flyers and other ephemera; artist portfolios; research files; documentaries; and interviews. Artists prominently documented in this collection include Eva Cockcroft, Janet Braun-Reinitz, and Camille Perrottet. Topics and themes include women's rights, community organizing, the African diaspora, and New York City neighborhoods. This collection also includes materials produced during the writing and publishing of On the Wall: Four Decades of Community Murals in New York City, a history of community murals in New York City.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

controlaccess.subject: Art -- Political aspects.
Mural painting and decoration -- United States.
street art
Public art spaces.
Politics in art.

physdesc.extent: in 4 manuscript boxes, 1 half manuscript box, 1 small flat box, and 1 oversized flat box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of administrative materials created by Artmakers in the course of its daily operations. Also included are administrative materials from Cityarts Workshop, mostly from the time before Artmakers was formed and during its early years. Materials include historical documents (e.g., articles of incorporation), general correspondence, grant proposals, financial documents, artists' files (if they participated with the group), permissions, conference submissions and proposals, and lecture notes/other presentation materials (e.g., PowerPoints). Artists' files, mostly of artists who collaborated with Artmakers, include slides, biographies, art reviews, writing, and exhibition postcards, mostly for events not sponsored by Artmakers but related to murals and/or community art. Additionally, there are audiotapes and a videotape of Eva Cockcroft's memorial service, an interview with Jane Weissman about the history of murals in New York City, and flyers and brochures of Social and Public Art Resource Center (SPARC), a similar organziation to Artmakers, located in Los Angeles, California.

did.unittitle: Series II. Murals, Exhibitions, and Projects

physdesc.extent: in 8 manuscript boxes, 3 half manuscript boxes, 5 small flat boxes, 8 oversized flat boxes, 2 rolled storage boxes, 16 flat file folders, and 6 folders in 3 oversized boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains production-related materials for each mural, exhibition, or project supported by Artmakers, either independently or in collaboration with other organizations (such as Operation Greenthumb and United Community Centers). Documentation about murals sponsored by Cityarts Workshop and painted by artists who collaborated with Artmakers are included here. All of the materials reflect the organization's commitment to involving the community in the creation of its murals. Materials, in paper and electronic formats, include correspondence, photographs, preparatory drawings and paintings, press releases, postcards, exhibition programs, painting schedules, and budgets. Materials related to the publication of On the Wall: Four Decades of Community Murals in New York City include a prospectus, grant application, background/research materials, correspondence with the publisher, press clippings, and photographs.
